verb.description: (of a person's skin, face, etc.) become red and hot, typically as the result of illness or strong emotion.
Cleanse (something, especially a toilet) by causing large quantities of water to pass through it.
examples: the nurse flushed out the catheter

verb.description: Drive (a bird, especially a game bird, or an animal) from its cover.
examples: the grouse were flushed from the woods

verb.description: (of a plant) send out fresh shoots.
examples: the plant had started to flush by late March

noun.description: A reddening of the face, skin, etc., typically caused by illness or strong emotion.
examples: a flush of embarrassment rose to her cheeks

noun.description: A sudden rush of intense emotion.
examples: I was carried away in a flush of enthusiasm

noun.description: An act of cleansing something, especially a toilet, with a sudden flow of water.
examples: an old-fashioned toilet uses six or seven gallons per flush
leave the hose running to give the system a good flush out

noun.description: The action of driving a game bird from its cover.
examples: the dogs retrieve the birds after the flush

adjective.description: Completely level or even with another surface.
examples: the gates are flush with the adjoining fencing

adjective.description: Having plenty of something, especially money.
examples: the banks are flush with funds

adverb.description: So as to be level or even.
examples: the screw must fit flush with the surface

origin: Late Middle English (in the sense marshy place): variant of flash.
